On Wed, 20 Aug 2003, Dave Astels wrote:

> > Briefly the problem is two "very simple" Java bean classes (A and
> > B).  Class A is really simple: a constructor with a number of
> > arguments and a host of accessor methods for retrieving this
> > (member) data.
>
> This sounds like a data class... why does it exist if it has no behaviour?

What else do you propose to do with a pile of data that belong together?
Split it up all over the place?

There's absoutely nothing wrong with data classes that have no behaviour.

You may be thinking of a problem that sounds similar but is in fact
different: behaviour that belongs in such a class but is instead
external. There's no indication to me in the post that this is the case.
